root.publications: Sagart, Laurent. 2005. Sino-Tibetan-Austronesian: An updated and improved argument. In Roger Blench, Laurent Sagart & Alicia Sanchez-Mazas (eds.), The Peopling of East Asia: Putting together archaeology, linguistics and genetics, 161-176. New York: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-32242-1, Sagart, Laurent. 2002. Sino-Tibetan-Austronesian: An updated and improved argument, Ninth International Conference on Austronesian Linguistics, 14.
root.pub-comments: “Since Tibeto-Burman and Chinese do have more basic vocabulary in common than either does with Proto-Austronesian and since some features shared by Tibeto-Burman and Chinese against Proto-Austronesian appear to be innovations (Sagart forthcoming), I recognise here (contra Sagart 1990) that Sino-Tibetan is a valid construct and claim that it, as a whole, is genetically related to Proto-Austronesian. I refer to the resulting macrophylum as Sino-Tibetan-Austronesian” (Sagart 2005:162).

child.publications: Sagart, Laurent. 2005. Sino-Tibetan-Austronesian: An updated and improved argument. In Roger Blench, Laurent Sagart & Alicia Sanchez-Mazas (eds.), The Peopling of East Asia: Putting together archaeology, linguistics and genetics, 161-176. New York: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-32242-1, Sagart, Laurent. 2002. Sino-Tibetan-Austronesian: An updated and improved argument, Ninth International Conference on Austronesian Linguistics, 14.
child.pub-comments: “I adhere to the view that Proto-Austronesian was spoken in Taiwan from around 5,500 BP on, on archaeological grounds” (Sagart 2005:161).

child.publications: Sagart, Laurent. 2005. Sino-Tibetan-Austronesian: An updated and improved argument. In Roger Blench, Laurent Sagart & Alicia Sanchez-Mazas (eds.), The Peopling of East Asia: Putting together archaeology, linguistics and genetics, 161-176. New York: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-32242-1, Sagart, Laurent. 2002. Sino-Tibetan-Austronesian: An updated and improved argument, Ninth International Conference on Austronesian Linguistics, 14.
child.pub-comments: “The first diversification of Proto-Austronesian took place on the West Coast of Taiwan. Soon one group of West coast speakers moved to the East coast where a second diversification occurred, resulting in a dialect linkage (East Coast Linkage)” (Sagart 2005:161).

child.publications: Sagart, Laurent. 2005. Sino-Tibetan-Austronesian: An updated and improved argument. In Roger Blench, Laurent Sagart & Alicia Sanchez-Mazas (eds.), The Peopling of East Asia: Putting together archaeology, linguistics and genetics, 161-176. New York: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-32242-1, Sagart, Laurent. 2002. Sino-Tibetan-Austronesian: An updated and improved argument, Ninth International Conference on Austronesian Linguistics, 14.
child.pub-comments: “Another group of early Austronesian speakers left Taiwan to settle the coastal areas in Guangdong or Guangxi, where their language, which I call Austronesian Ancestor of Kadai was to a great extent relexified by a local language, later to become Proto-Kadai (more on this in Chapter 10 ['Tai-Kadai as a subgroup of Austronesian'] , this volume)” (Sagart 2005:161).

child.publications: Sagart, Laurent. 2005. Sino-Tibetan-Austronesian: An updated and improved argument. In Roger Blench, Laurent Sagart & Alicia Sanchez-Mazas (eds.), The Peopling of East Asia: Putting together archaeology, linguistics and genetics, 161-176. New York: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-32242-1, Sagart, Laurent. 2002. Sino-Tibetan-Austronesian: An updated and improved argument, Ninth International Conference on Austronesian Linguistics, 14.

child.geography: The coastal areas in Guangdong or Guangxi

child.pub-comments: “Later on, perhaps around 4,500 BP, a group of East Coast Linkage speakers left Taiwan to settle the northern Philippines. Their language, Proto-Malayo-Polynesian, is ancestral to all conventionally recognised Austronesian languages outside of Taiwan” (Sagart 2005:161).

child.pub-comments: “Available reconstructions of Tibeto-Burman (Benedict 1972) and Sino-Tibetan (Coblin 1986; Gong 1995; Peiros and Starostin 1995) differ widely, due to continuing uncertainty on subgrouping, sound correspondences and the amount of contact between Chinese and the rest of Sino-Tibetan. For this reason, Old Chinese will serve here as the main representative of Sino-Tibetan” (Sagart 2005:162).
